sect2.para: This is my choice of package manager. Dpkg is the basic package manager of Debian. It can be complemented by deselect (in the same package), apt or aptitude. We use it in a very crude way.

sect2.title: Installation of Dpkg
sect2.para: Since Debian is shipping its own package, all patches have already been applied. However, the configure script calls dpkg itself, which is found only on Debian hosts. The following sed command prevents that call:

variablelist.title: The meaning of the configure options:

listitem.para: Avoids building dselect, an awful thing!
The utility start-stop-daemon is not needed here.
Debian install-info is a wrapper to install-info installed by Texinfo. Not needed either.

screen.userinput: (cd lib && make) (cd src && make) (cd dpkg-deb && make) (cd dpkg-split && make)

sect2.para: This package does not come with a test suite.

screen.userinput: cp src/dpkg src/dpkg-* /tools/bin cp dpkg-deb/dpkg-deb /tools/bin cp dpkg-split/dpkg-split /tools/bin mkdir -pv /tools/etc/dpkg/{,dpkg.cfg.d} cp debian/dpkg.cfg /tools/etc/dpkg

sect2.para: Add a line in dpkg.cfg to tell where to put administration files

screen.userinput: cat >> /tools/etc/dpkg/dpkg.cfg << EOF # admindir on LFS system admindir /var/lib/dpkg EOF

sect2.para: On a Debian system, dpkg relies on two other files to be present. Since we do not install them, issue:

screen.userinput: cat >> /tools/etc/dpkg/dpkg.cfg << EOF # disable fatal error on path checking force-bad-path EOF

sect1.title: Adding Directories for package management
sect1.para: Those directories should be added to the system. /var/lib/dpkg and subdirectories are adminitrative directories of dpkg. /var/log is the log directory for dpkg. /var/lib/packages will be used to store our packages.deb files.

sect1.title: Adding administrative files for Dpkg
sect1.para: dpkg needs that some files exist to run for the first time. The log file must exist in order to be used.

sect2.para: This is my choice of package manager. Dpkg is the basic package manager of Debian. It can be complemented by deselect (in the same package), apt or aptitude. We use it in a very crude way.

sect2.title: Installation of Dpkg
sect2.para: Since Debian is shipping its own package, all patches have already been applied. We can go directly to configuring it:

variablelist.title: The meaning of the configure options:

listitem.para: Avoids building dselect, an awful thing!
The utility start-stop-daemon is not needed here.
Debian install-info is a wrapper to install-info installed by Texinfo. Not needed either.

sect2.para: This package does not come with a test suite.

screen.userinput: mkdir -pv $PKG_DEST make DESTDIR=$PKG_DEST install mkdir -pv $PKG_DEST/etc/dpkg/{,dpkg.cfg.d} cp debian/dpkg.cfg $PKG_DEST/etc/dpkg

sect2.para: Add a line in dpkg.cfg to tell where to put administration files

screen.userinput: cat >> $PKG_DEST/etc/dpkg/dpkg.cfg << EOF # admindir on LFS system admindir /var/lib/dpkg EOF

sect2.para: On a Debian system, dpkg relies on two other files (ldconfig and maybe update-rc.d) to be present. Since we do not install them, issue:
